stories.title: The current thing is truth. Arguments against current thing are misinformation
You only need to test with 5 users [2000]

stories.text:
In contrast to most devs, I use plain Javascript in my projects. No react, no server side compilation, nothing. Especially now that we have modules supported in the browser, it is lovely!

But I don't like that all my code is out in the open verbatim.

What is a good way to obfuscate it? Preferably some command line tool that I can unleash onto a directory, and it will obfuscate every js file it finds in there, including subdirs.
stories.title: Ask HN: What's a good way to obfuscate my JavaScript code?

stories.text:
We're launching our product for early access which is an alternative for Netlify + Heroku, tomorrow.

I've had three goals for this product: - Simplicity - Performance - Low price (I particularly wanted to make this an awesome choice for IHs)

It currently supports static websites and dockerized web applications.

This is going to be one a few releases in the next few weeks weeks. Ultimately, whoever is involved will get a massive discount. Also your feedback will quite literally impact the product the way you want.

The only requirement is that you should be a paying user of a PaaS provider (Netlify, Heroku, Vercel, etc.) now or have been one in the past (it's just about the accuracy of the feedbacks)

Please let me know here or DM me on Twitter (MohsenKamranii).
stories.title: Push your code, see the result
